title: Question 11
prompt: Paula notices that when she wears her polarized sunglasses and looks at her LCD (liquid crystal display) clock with her head tilted at a certain angle, when the polarizers are at X<sup>o</sup>, she cannot see the display. She realizes that the light from the LCD must be polarized. At what angle is the light from the LCD?
description:
Click the one best answer to each question.

Polarized sunglasses are designed to block bright, reflected glare. They work because sunlight reflecting off flat surfaces creates polarized waves, that is, waves that all vibrate in the same direction. Polarized sunglasses block these waves with “polarizers,” as shown in the diagram.
feedback:
The polarized sunglasses block polarized waves, or waves that vibrate in a particular direction. When the direction of the polarizers in the glasses is perpendicular to the waves, the light is blocked. The waves from the LCD must all be vibrating perpendicular to the angle that Paula holds her head when she cannot see the LCD display. The waves blocked and the polarizers are perpendicular to each other.


Polarized sunglasses are designed to block bright, reflected glare. They work because sunlight reflecting off flat surfaces creates horizontally polarized waves, that is, waves that vibrate parallel to the ground. Polarized sunglasses block these waves with vertical “polarizers,” perpendicular to the ground.
